list_definition.definition: loosely woven woollen/woolen cloth usually soft and slightly furry

list_ex_of_english: The main industries, chiefly for home consumption, were flannels, stockings and bundle cloth.
The song begins with the squeaky voice of a market hawker shouting, four for a pound your face flannels; three for a pound your tea towels!
Their flannels had black and orange piping with matching socks, perhaps recalling also those of its emblem, the "tiger".
I responded with a wee bit of politicians' faff—a bit of flannel.
Indeed, some were so great that they were allowed to wear grey flannel trousers.
I think that it is a lawyer's word for flannel.
I remember the agony of the appeal of a distressed purchaser of some 17,000,000 yards of flannel.
I was also interested in what he said about the gentleman who told him that women will come back to red flannel for their bloomers sooner or later.
